title: Read Entire File
description: Read and print the contents of 'sample.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('sample.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Hello, World!\nWelcome to Python.')
hints: Use open('sample.txt', 'r') to open in read mode
Use .read() to get all contents, or use 'with' statement

title: Read File Line by Line
description: Read 'data.txt' and print each line (strip whitespace).
setupCode:
with open('data.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Line 1\nLine 2\nLine 3')
hints: Use .readlines() or iterate directly over the file object
Use .strip() to remove newline characters

title: Read Specific Line
description: Read and print only the second line from 'numbers.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('numbers.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('First\nSecond\nThird')
hints: Read all lines into a list with .readlines()
Access the line at index 1 (second line)

title: Write to File
description: Write 'Hello, Python!' to a new file called 'output.txt'.
hints: Use open('output.txt', 'w') for write mode
Use .write() method to write content

title: Write Multiple Lines
description: Write three lines to 'lines.txt': 'First', 'Second', 'Third'.
hints: Use \n to add newlines between content
Or use .writelines() with a list of strings

title: Append to File
description: Append 'New line' to the existing 'log.txt' file.
setupCode:
with open('log.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Existing content')
testCode:
with open('log.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Existing content')
{user_code}
with open('log.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Use 'a' mode for append: open('log.txt', 'a')
Append mode adds to the end without erasing existing content

title: Using With Statement
description: Use 'with' statement to read and print 'test.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('test.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Using with statement')
hints: with open('test.txt', 'r') as f: automatically closes the file
No need to call .close() explicitly

title: Check if File Exists
description: Check if 'myfile.txt' exists and print True or False.
setupCode:
import os
with open('myfile.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('test')
testCode:
import os
with open('myfile.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('test')
{user_code}
hints: Use os.path.exists('myfile.txt')
Returns True if file exists, False otherwise

title: Count Lines in File
description: Count and print the number of lines in 'document.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('document.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Line 1
Line 2
Line 3
Line 4')
testCode:
with open('document.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Line 1
Line 2
Line 3
Line 4')
{user_code}
hints: Read lines with .readlines() and use len()
Or iterate and count

title: Count Words in File
description: Count total words in 'text.txt' and print the count.
setupCode:
with open('text.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Hello world\nPython is great')
hints: Read the file and use .split() to separate words
Count the total number of words across all lines

title: Search for Word in File
description: Check if the word 'Python' exists in 'search.txt'. Print True or False.
setupCode:
with open('search.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('I love Python programming\nIt is awesome')
hints: Read the file content and use 'in' operator
Check if 'Python' in file_content

title: Copy File Contents
description: Copy contents from 'source.txt' to 'destination.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('source.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Content to copy')
testCode:
with open('source.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Content to copy')
{user_code}
with open('destination.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read from source.txt
Write the content to destination.txt

title: Reverse Line Order
description: Read 'input.txt' and write lines in reverse order to 'reversed.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('input.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('First\nSecond\nThird')
testCode:
with open('input.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('First\nSecond\nThird')
{user_code}
with open('reversed.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read all lines into a list
Reverse the list and write to new file

title: Filter Lines by Keyword
description: Write only lines containing 'error' from 'log.txt' to 'errors.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('log.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('info: all good
error: failed
warning: check this
error: timeout')
testCode:
with open('log.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('info: all good\nerror: failed\nwarning: check this\nerror: timeout')
{user_code}
with open('errors.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read lines from log.txt
Check if 'error' in line, then write to errors.txt

title: Convert File to Uppercase
description: Read 'lowercase.txt' and write uppercase version to 'uppercase.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('lowercase.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('hello world\npython programming')
testCode:
with open('lowercase.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('hello world\npython programming')
{user_code}
with open('uppercase.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read content from lowercase.txt
Use .upper() method and write to uppercase.txt

title: Read CSV File
description: Read 'data.csv' and print each row as a list.
setupCode:
import csv
with open('data.csv', 'w') as f:
    f.write('name,age,city\nAlice,30,NYC\nBob,25,LA')
testCode:
import csv
with open('data.csv', 'w') as f:
    f.write('name,age,city\nAlice,30,NYC\nBob,25,LA')
{user_code}
hints: Use csv.reader() to read CSV files
Iterate through the reader object to get rows

title: Write CSV File
description: Write data to 'output.csv' with headers: name,score and rows: Alice,95 and Bob,87.
hints: Use csv.writer() to write CSV files
Use .writerow() for each row

title: Read JSON File
description: Read 'data.json' and print the value of the 'name' key.
setupCode:
import json
with open('data.json', 'w') as f:
    json.dump({'name': 'Alice', 'age': 30}, f)
testCode:
import json
with open('data.json', 'w') as f:
    json.dump({'name': 'Alice', 'age': 30}, f)
{user_code}
hints: Use json.load() to read JSON files
Access dictionary keys from the loaded data

title: Write JSON File
description: Write a dictionary {'title': 'Python', 'year': 2024} to 'book.json'.
hints: Use json.dump() to write JSON files
Pass the dictionary and file object to json.dump()

title: Handle File Not Found
description: Try to read 'nonexistent.txt', catch the exception, and print 'File not found'.
testCode: {user_code}
hints: Use try-except block
Catch FileNotFoundError exception

title: Read Numbers and Calculate Sum
description: Read numbers from 'numbers.txt' (one per line) and print their sum.
setupCode:
with open('numbers.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('10
20
30
40')
testCode:
with open('numbers.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('10
20
30
40')
{user_code}
hints: Read lines and convert each to int
Sum all the numbers

title: Write List to File
description: Write items from list ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry'] to 'fruits.txt', one per line.
testCode:
fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
{user_code}
with open('fruits.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Loop through the list
Write each item with a newline character

title: Read File into List
description: Read 'items.txt' and create a list of items (stripped). Print the list.
setupCode:
with open('items.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Item1\nItem2\nItem3')
hints: Use .readlines() or iterate over the file
Strip whitespace from each line and add to list

title: Check if File is Empty
description: Check if 'empty.txt' is empty and print True or False.
setupCode:
with open('empty.txt', 'w') as f:
    pass
hints: Use os.path.getsize('empty.txt')
If size is 0, file is empty

title: Remove Duplicate Lines
description: Read 'duplicates.txt' and write unique lines to 'unique.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('duplicates.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('apple
banana
apple
cherry
banana')
testCode:
with open('duplicates.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('apple\nbanana\napple\ncherry\nbanana')
{user_code}
with open('unique.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read lines into a set to remove duplicates
Write the unique lines to new file

title: Merge Multiple Files
description: Merge contents of 'file1.txt' and 'file2.txt' into 'merged.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('file1.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Content from file 1')
with open('file2.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Content from file 2')
testCode:
with open('file1.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Content from file 1')
with open('file2.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Content from file 2')
{user_code}
with open('merged.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read from both files
Write both contents to merged.txt

title: Replace Text in File
description: Replace all occurrences of 'old' with 'new' in 'text.txt' and save the result.
setupCode:
with open('text.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('This is old text with old words')
expectedOutput: This is new text with new words
testCode:
with open('text.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('This is old text with old words')
{user_code}
with open('text.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read the file content
Use .replace('old', 'new') and write back to file

title: Write Binary File
description: Write bytes b'Binary data' to 'data.bin'.
hints: Use 'wb' mode for binary write
Write bytes object directly

title: Read Binary File
description: Read and print the binary content from 'data.bin'.
setupCode:
with open('data.bin', 'wb') as f:
    f.write(b'Binary content')
hints: Use 'rb' mode for binary read
Print the bytes object

title: File Position - Seek and Tell
description: Open 'position.txt', seek to position 6, and print the rest of the content.
setupCode:
with open('position.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Hello World')
hints: Use .seek(6) to move to position 6
Use .read() to get remaining content

title: Word Frequency Counter
description: Count frequency of each word in 'words.txt' and print as dictionary.
setupCode:
with open('words.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('hello world hello python world')
hints: Read and split the content into words
Use a dictionary to count occurrences

title: Add Line Numbers
description: Read 'input.txt' and write to 'numbered.txt' with line numbers (1: First line...).
setupCode:
with open('input.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('First line\nSecond line\nThird line')
expectedOutput:
1: First line
2: Second line
3: Third line
testCode:
with open('input.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('First line\nSecond line\nThird line')
{user_code}
with open('numbered.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Use enumerate() with start=1
Format each line with number prefix

title: Find Longest Line
description: Find and print the longest line from 'lines.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('lines.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Short\nThis is a longer line\nMedium line')
hints: Read all lines and compare lengths
Use max() with key=len

title: Sort File Lines
description: Read 'unsorted.txt' and write sorted lines to 'sorted.txt'.
setupCode:
with open('unsorted.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('zebra
apple
mango
banana')
testCode:
with open('unsorted.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('zebra\napple\nmango\nbanana')
{user_code}
with open('sorted.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Read lines into a list
Sort the list and write to new file

title: CSV with DictReader
description: Read 'people.csv' using DictReader and print each row's 'name' value.
setupCode:
import csv
with open('people.csv', 'w') as f:
    f.write('name,age\nAlice,30\nBob,25')
testCode:
import csv
with open('people.csv', 'w') as f:
    f.write('name,age\nAlice,30\nBob,25')
{user_code}
hints: Use csv.DictReader() to read CSV as dictionaries
Access values using row['name']

title: CSV with DictWriter
description: Write dictionaries to 'output.csv' using DictWriter with fieldnames=['name', 'score'].
testCode:
import csv
data = [{'name': 'Alice', 'score': 95}, {'name': 'Bob', 'score': 87}]
{user_code}
with open('output.csv', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Use csv.DictWriter() with fieldnames
Use .writeheader() and .writerows()

title: Multiple Files in Context Manager
description: Open 'input.txt' for reading and 'output.txt' for writing in single with statement, copy content.
setupCode:
with open('input.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Copy this content')
testCode:
with open('input.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Copy this content')
{user_code}
with open('output.txt', 'r') as f:
    print(f.read())
hints: Use with open(...) as f1, open(...) as f2:
Read from f1 and write to f2

title: Create Directory
description: Create a directory called 'new_folder'.
testCode:
{user_code}
print(os.path.exists('new_folder'))
hints: Use os.mkdir('new_folder')
Or os.makedirs() for nested directories

title: List Directory Contents
description: Create files 'a.txt' and 'b.txt' in current directory, then list all files (sorted).
testCode: {user_code}
hints: Create the files first
Use os.listdir('.') to list files in current directory

title: Delete File
description: Create 'temp.txt' and then delete it. Print True if deletion successful.
testCode: {user_code}
hints: Create the file first with open()
Use os.remove('temp.txt') to delete

title: Rename File
description: Create 'old_name.txt' and rename it to 'new_name.txt'. Print True if new file exists.
testCode: {user_code}
hints: Create the file first
Use os.rename('old_name.txt', 'new_name.txt')
